title: Police question cake-baker accused of 'inciting violence' after Facebook 'machete' joke
text:
Police questioned a farmers’ market cake stall-owner after he was accused of “inciting violence” against the council he blamed for melting his creations.

Two officers visited baker George Hepher at home after he called on his Facebook followers to protest with “banners and machetes" the decision to give him a stall in direct sunlight

The baker, whose been a popular fixture at the St Ives Farmers Market in Cambridgeshire since 2015, said the post was meant in jest and described the council’s response as “ludicrous” and “a huge overreaction.”

The dispute started in June when the council moved Mr Hepher’s stall from a central berth in the market to a larger one on the periphery that was lacking shade.

Mr Hepher soon complained as the hot summer's glare began melting his chocolate rocky roads and collapsing butter-cream cakes, costing him up to £500 a day in wasted stock.

After a particularly frustrating day at his stall last month, the young baker vented his frustration in a Facebook post to his customers as he settled down to watch Strictly. On Tuesday St Ives council announced Mr Hepher, who lives in the neighbouring village of Needingworth, was banned from the market over social media posts that “appeared to be inciting violence against the town council and its staff”
description: Police questioned a farmers’ market cake stall-owner after he was accused of “inciting violence” against the council he blamed for melting his creations.
